metadata.title: Healthy Foods Database for Marathon Runners
metadata.description: Comprehensive nutrition database optimized for female endurance athletes
references: Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition
American College of Sports Medicine Guidelines

categories.name: Nuts & Seeds
categories.description: Nutrient-dense sources of healthy fats, protein, and minerals essential for endurance performance

foods.name: Chia Seeds
benefits: Exceptional omega-3 content supports cardiovascular health and reduces exercise-induced inflammation
High fiber content promotes sustained energy release during long runs
Hydrophilic properties help maintain hydration during endurance events
Rich in antioxidants that combat oxidative stress from intense training
foods.notes: Can absorb 10x their weight in water - excellent for pre-race hydration. Add to overnight oats or smoothies 2-3 hours before running.

foods.name: Almonds
benefits: Vitamin E protects muscle cells from oxidative damage during intense exercise
Magnesium supports muscle function and prevents cramping
Sustained energy from healthy fats ideal for endurance training
B vitamins support energy metabolism during long runs
foods.notes: Best consumed raw or dry-roasted without added oils. Excellent portable snack for training days.

foods.name: Walnuts
benefits: Highest omega-3 content among nuts reduces post-exercise inflammation
Polyphenols and antioxidants support brain health and cognitive function
May improve arterial function and blood flow during exercise
Supports recovery by reducing inflammatory markers after training
foods.notes: Best for recovery days due to anti-inflammatory properties. Store in refrigerator to preserve omega-3s.

foods.name: Pumpkin Seeds (Pepitas)
benefits: Exceptional magnesium content prevents muscle cramps and supports recovery
Iron supports oxygen transport crucial for endurance performance
Zinc supports immune function stressed by intense training
High protein content supports muscle repair and synthesis
foods.notes: Excellent source of plant-based iron for female athletes. Pair with vitamin C foods to enhance iron absorption.

foods.name: Ground Flaxseeds
benefits: Richest plant source of omega-3 fatty acids for reducing inflammation
Lignans provide antioxidant and hormone-balancing effects
Soluble fiber promotes gut health and steady energy release
May help reduce blood pressure and support cardiovascular health
foods.notes: Must be ground to access nutrients. Store ground flax in freezer. Add to smoothies, oatmeal, or baked goods.

foods.name: Hemp Seeds (Hearts)
benefits: Complete protein with all essential amino acids for muscle recovery
Optimal omega-6 to omega-3 ratio (3:1) for reducing inflammation
Exceptional magnesium content prevents cramping during long runs
Easily digestible protein ideal for pre or post-workout meals
foods.notes: One of few complete plant proteins. Mild nutty flavor works in smoothies, salads, or yogurt.

foods.name: Brazil Nuts
benefits: Richest food source of selenium - crucial for thyroid function and metabolism
Selenium acts as powerful antioxidant protecting against exercise-induced oxidative stress
Supports immune function during high-volume training phases
May help reduce inflammation markers in athletes
foods.notes: Limit to 3-4 nuts daily due to extremely high selenium content. Excellent for thyroid support in female athletes.

foods.name: Pistachios
benefits: Highest B6 content among nuts supports energy metabolism and hemoglobin production
Lutein and zeaxanthin support eye health during outdoor training
Lower calorie than most nuts with excellent protein content
Potassium helps maintain electrolyte balance during long runs
foods.notes: Choose in-shell pistachios to slow consumption and increase mindful eating. Great post-run snack.

foods.name: Sunflower Seeds
benefits: Exceptional vitamin E content protects muscles from oxidative damage
Selenium and copper support antioxidant enzyme systems
B vitamins support energy production during endurance exercise
Phytosterols support healthy cholesterol levels
foods.notes: Choose unsalted for everyday consumption. Excellent addition to trail mix for long training runs.

foods.name: Cashews
benefits: High copper content supports iron metabolism and red blood cell formation
Magnesium and zinc support muscle function and immune health
Lower fat content than most nuts with creamy satisfying texture
Iron supports oxygen transport for endurance performance
foods.notes: Higher in carbs than other nuts - can be useful for quick energy. Cashew butter is excellent in smoothies.

categories.name: Green Vegetables
categories.description: Nutrient-dense greens providing essential vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants for optimal performance and recovery

foods.name: Spinach
benefits: Natural nitrates improve oxygen efficiency and reduce oxygen cost during exercise
Vitamin K supports bone health essential for high-impact training
Folate supports red blood cell production for oxygen transport
Iron content (enhanced when cooked) supports endurance performance in female athletes
foods.notes: Consume raw in smoothies or lightly cooked. Nitrate benefits peak 2-3 hours after consumption - time pre-race accordingly.

foods.name: Kale
benefits: Exceptionally high vitamin K supports bone density crucial for runners
Vitamin C supports collagen synthesis for connective tissue health
Powerful antioxidants (quercetin, kaempferol) combat exercise-induced oxidative stress
Beta-carotene supports immune function during high training loads
foods.notes: Massage raw kale with lemon juice to soften and improve nutrient absorption. Excellent in post-run smoothies.

foods.name: Broccoli
benefits: Sulforaphane activates Nrf2 pathway for powerful cellular protection
High vitamin C supports immune function and iron absorption
Fiber promotes gut health and steady energy levels
Potassium supports electrolyte balance during endurance exercise
foods.notes: Light steaming preserves nutrients while making sulforaphane more bioavailable. Chew thoroughly to activate compounds.

foods.name: Arugula (Rocket)
benefits: Highest nitrate content among leafy greens improves exercise efficiency
Glucosinolates provide potent anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects
Low calorie density with high nutrient concentration
Peppery compounds may support healthy blood pressure
foods.notes: Excellent pre-race food due to exceptional nitrate content. Add to salads or sandwiches 2-3 hours before running.

foods.name: Bok Choy
benefits: Excellent calcium source with high bioavailability for bone health
Vitamin C and A support immune function and tissue repair
Low oxalate content means better mineral absorption than spinach
Cruciferous compounds support detoxification and recovery
foods.notes: One of the best plant-based calcium sources for female athletes. Excellent in stir-fries and soups.

foods.name: Swiss Chard
benefits: Exceptional vitamin K content supports bone health and blood clotting
Betalain pigments provide unique antioxidant and anti-inflammatory benefits
Magnesium supports muscle relaxation and prevents cramping
Syringic acid may help regulate blood sugar for steady energy
foods.notes: Rainbow chard contains additional betalain antioxidants. Sautee with garlic for maximum flavor.

foods.name: Brussels Sprouts
benefits: High fiber content promotes gut health and satiety for weight management
Glucosinolates support detoxification pathways stressed by intense exercise
Excellent vitamin C supports collagen synthesis for joint health
ALA omega-3 content provides anti-inflammatory benefits
foods.notes: Roast at high heat to caramelize and reduce bitterness. Avoid eating too close to runs due to fiber content.

foods.name: Asparagus
benefits: Exceptional folate content supports red blood cell production
Natural diuretic properties help reduce bloating before races
Prebiotic fiber supports gut microbiome health
Glutathione content provides powerful antioxidant protection
foods.notes: Contains inulin prebiotic fiber for gut health. Roast or grill for best flavor.

foods.name: Green Beans
benefits: Silicon content supports bone and connective tissue health
Moderate fiber content is easier to digest than other high-fiber vegetables
Chlorophyll supports blood health and oxygen transport
Antioxidants support recovery from exercise-induced oxidative stress
foods.notes: One of the easier-to-digest green vegetables. Good option closer to training if sensitive to high-fiber foods.

foods.name: Collard Greens
benefits: Exceptional calcium with high bioavailability for bone health
Glucosinolates provide strong anti-inflammatory effects
High vitamin K supports bone metabolism in female athletes
Fiber supports healthy digestion and blood sugar control
foods.notes: Remove tough stems before cooking. Braise or sautee until tender for best digestibility.

categories.name: Fruits
categories.description: Natural sources of quick energy, antioxidants, and essential vitamins for performance and recovery

foods.name: Blueberries
benefits: Anthocyanins shown to accelerate muscle recovery and reduce DOMS
Improve brain function and cognitive performance during fatigue
Reduce exercise-induced oxidative stress and inflammation
May improve insulin sensitivity and glycogen replenishment
foods.notes: Research shows 200-300g daily during heavy training reduces muscle damage markers. Frozen retain most nutrients.

foods.name: Tart Cherries (Montmorency)
benefits: Strong research showing reduced muscle soreness and faster recovery
Natural melatonin content supports quality sleep for recovery
Reduces inflammation markers (CRP, IL-6) after intense exercise
May reduce muscle strength loss following eccentric exercise
foods.notes: Tart cherry juice (8-12oz) before and after marathons significantly reduces recovery time. Natural sleep aid.

foods.name: Banana
benefits: Ideal quick energy source with easily digestible carbohydrates
Potassium helps prevent muscle cramps during endurance exercise
Natural packaging makes it perfect portable fuel for long runs
B6 supports energy metabolism and hemoglobin synthesis
foods.notes: Ripe bananas (with spots) digest faster for quick energy. Less ripe have more resistant starch for sustained energy.

foods.name: Orange
benefits: High vitamin C supports immune function stressed by marathon training
Enhances iron absorption when eaten with iron-rich foods
Hesperidin flavonoid supports blood vessel health and circulation
Natural sugars provide quick energy with hydrating water content
foods.notes: Classic post-race recovery fruit. Pair with iron-rich foods to enhance absorption. Orange slices at mile 20 are a marathon tradition.

foods.name: Strawberries
benefits: Exceptional vitamin C boosts immune function and collagen synthesis
Low glycemic index provides sustained energy without blood sugar spikes
Ellagic acid supports muscle recovery and reduces inflammation
High water content aids hydration
foods.notes: Best eaten in season for maximum nutrient content. Excellent in recovery smoothies with protein.

foods.name: Medjool Dates
benefits: Natural energy gel alternative with easily digestible sugars
High potassium prevents cramping during long runs
Perfect for mid-run fueling with portable natural packaging
Antioxidants reduce oxidative stress from endurance exercise
foods.notes: Excellent natural alternative to energy gels. Stuff with almond butter for sustained energy during long runs.

foods.name: Pomegranate Seeds
benefits: Punicalagins are exceptionally potent antioxidants for recovery
Nitrates improve exercise efficiency and blood flow
Reduces muscle soreness and accelerates strength recovery
Supports cardiovascular health for endurance performance
foods.notes: Pomegranate juice (8oz) pre-exercise shown to improve running time trial performance. Excellent for recovery smoothies.

foods.name: Watermelon
benefits: L-citrulline reduces muscle soreness and improves recovery
High water content (92%) excellent for hydration
Lycopene provides powerful antioxidant protection
Natural sugars replenish glycogen stores post-exercise
foods.notes: Watermelon juice post-exercise reduces muscle soreness. Cold watermelon is refreshing recovery food after hot runs.

foods.name: Apple
benefits: Quercetin may improve endurance and reduce fatigue during exercise
Pectin fiber supports gut health and steady energy release
Portable natural fuel with balanced carbohydrates
Polyphenols support cardiovascular health
foods.notes: Eat with skin for maximum quercetin. Pair with nut butter for sustained energy. Good pre-run option 1-2 hours before.

foods.name: Kiwi
benefits: Exceptionally high vitamin C content exceeds oranges by 2x
Actinidin enzyme aids protein digestion for better recovery
Shown to improve sleep quality essential for recovery
High potassium content prevents muscle cramps
foods.notes: Eat 2 kiwis before bed to improve sleep quality (research-supported). Can eat skin for extra fiber and nutrients.

categories.name: Legumes
categories.description: Excellent plant-based protein and complex carbohydrate sources for sustained energy and recovery

foods.name: Lentils (Cooked)
benefits: Exceptional iron content crucial for female endurance athletes
High protein supports muscle repair and synthesis
Complex carbs provide sustained energy for long training sessions
Folate supports red blood cell production for oxygen transport
foods.notes: Red lentils cook fastest (15 min) and are easier to digest. Pair with vitamin C foods to enhance iron absorption.

foods.name: Chickpeas (Cooked)
benefits: Complete amino acid profile when combined with grains
High fiber promotes satiety and stable blood sugar
Excellent source of plant-based iron for female athletes
Versatile - works in hummus, salads, curries, and snacks
foods.notes: Roasted chickpeas make excellent crunchy snacks. Hummus is a perfect recovery food with whole grain bread.

foods.name: Black Beans (Cooked)
benefits: Anthocyanins in skin provide powerful antioxidant protection
High magnesium prevents muscle cramps during long runs
Resistant starch supports gut health and stable energy
Excellent protein-carb ratio for recovery meals
foods.notes: Don't drain the liquid - it contains water-soluble nutrients. Perfect in burritos, bowls, and soups.

foods.name: Edamame (Shelled)
benefits: Complete protein with all essential amino acids
Highest protein content among legumes per serving
Isoflavones may support bone health in female athletes
Quick to prepare - perfect for busy training schedules
foods.notes: Keep frozen edamame on hand for quick protein. Steam and sprinkle with sea salt for a perfect recovery snack.

foods.name: Kidney Beans (Cooked)
benefits: High potassium content supports electrolyte balance
Excellent source of plant-based iron for endurance
Resistant starch feeds beneficial gut bacteria
Steady energy release from complex carbohydrates
foods.notes: Must be thoroughly cooked - never eat raw or undercooked. Great in chili, salads, and grain bowls.

foods.name: Navy Beans (Cooked)
benefits: Highest fiber content among common beans for gut health
Excellent source of resistant starch for sustained energy
High iron and folate support red blood cell production
Potassium helps prevent muscle cramping
foods.notes: Traditional baked bean variety. High fiber means eat well before running to avoid GI issues.

foods.name: Pinto Beans (Cooked)
benefits: Selenium supports thyroid function and antioxidant defense
High folate crucial for female athletes of childbearing age
Excellent protein-to-carb ratio for muscle recovery
Promotes healthy gut bacteria diversity
foods.notes: Staple in Mexican cuisine. Make refried beans with minimal oil for healthy burritos.

foods.name: Split Peas (Cooked)
benefits: Isoflavones support bone health in female athletes
High fiber promotes satiety and weight management
B vitamins support energy metabolism during training
Easily digestible compared to whole legumes
foods.notes: No soaking required - cook in 25-30 minutes. Perfect for hearty recovery soups.

foods.name: Cannellini Beans (Cooked)
benefits: Highest iron content among white beans for endurance
Exceptional potassium prevents cramping during marathons
Creamy texture makes them versatile for many dishes
Good source of plant-based protein for muscle recovery
foods.notes: Blend into dips or soups for creamy texture without added fat. Great in Italian dishes like minestrone.

foods.name: Mung Beans (Cooked)
benefits: Easiest legume to digest - gentle on the stomach
Excellent folate content for red blood cell production
Sprouted form even more nutritious and digestible
High magnesium prevents muscle cramps
foods.notes: Sprout at home for maximum nutrition. Popular in Asian cuisine - excellent in dal or sprouted in salads.

categories.name: Whole Grains
categories.description: Complex carbohydrates providing sustained energy, fiber, and essential minerals for endurance performance

foods.name: Steel-Cut Oats
benefits: Beta-glucan fiber provides sustained energy release for long runs
Low glycemic index prevents blood sugar crashes during training
Ideal pre-race breakfast - easily digestible and filling
Supports healthy cholesterol and cardiovascular health
foods.notes: Classic marathon morning breakfast. Eat 2-3 hours before running. Add banana and honey for quick energy.

foods.name: Quinoa (Cooked)
benefits: Complete protein with all 9 essential amino acids for recovery
High magnesium content prevents muscle cramps
Gluten-free option for sensitive athletes
Cooks quickly (15 min) for convenient meal prep
foods.notes: Rinse before cooking to remove bitter saponins. Tri-color quinoa adds visual variety with same nutrition.

foods.name: Brown Rice (Cooked)
benefits: Excellent carbohydrate source for glycogen replenishment
Selenium supports thyroid function and antioxidant defense
Gentle on stomach - well-tolerated by most runners
Provides sustained energy without blood sugar spikes
foods.notes: Cook in batch and refrigerate - reheated rice has more resistant starch. Pairs well with any protein.

foods.name: Farro (Cooked)
benefits: Ancient grain with higher protein than most grains
Chewy texture satisfying for hearty recovery meals
Zinc supports immune function stressed by training
Complex carbs provide extended energy release
foods.notes: Pearled farro cooks faster (20 min). Nutty flavor excellent in grain salads and soups.

foods.name: Buckwheat Groats (Cooked)
benefits: Gluten-free despite the name (not related to wheat)
Rutin strengthens blood vessels and improves circulation
Complete protein profile for a grain
Lower glycemic index than many grains for steady energy
foods.notes: Soba noodles are made from buckwheat. Toast groats before cooking for nuttier flavor.

foods.name: Hulled Barley (Cooked)
benefits: Highest beta-glucan content of all grains for heart health
Exceptional soluble fiber supports steady blood sugar
Selenium supports thyroid and immune function
Very filling for weight management during training
foods.notes: Hulled barley retains more nutrients than pearled. Excellent in soups and grain bowls.

foods.name: Wild Rice (Cooked)
benefits: Higher protein content than other rice varieties
Zinc supports immune function and wound healing
Lower calorie than brown rice with more protein
Antioxidant content higher than white rice
foods.notes: Actually an aquatic grass, not true rice. Mix with brown rice for variety. Takes 45-60 min to cook.

foods.name: Millet (Cooked)
benefits: Alkaline grain that's gentle on the digestive system
Gluten-free option with good mineral content
Quick cooking time (20 min) for busy training days
Magnesium supports muscle function and recovery
foods.notes: Toast before cooking for nuttier flavor. Can be cooked fluffy like rice or creamy like polenta.

foods.name: Amaranth (Cooked)
benefits: Exceptional magnesium content prevents muscle cramps
High iron content crucial for female endurance athletes
Complete protein with lysine often lacking in grains
Gluten-free with excellent mineral density
foods.notes: Cooks to porridge-like consistency. Ancient Aztec superfood. Pop like popcorn for crunchy topping.

foods.name: Teff (Cooked)
benefits: Exceptional iron content - highest among grains for female athletes
Ethiopian runners' traditional grain linked to their endurance success
High resistant starch content for gut health
Complete amino acid profile for muscle recovery
foods.notes: Staple of Ethiopian marathon champions. Used to make injera bread. Smallest grain - cooks in 20 min.

categories.name: Lean Proteins
categories.description: High-quality protein sources essential for muscle repair, recovery, and maintaining lean body mass during training

foods.name: Wild Salmon
benefits: EPA and DHA omega-3s reduce exercise-induced inflammation significantly
Vitamin D supports bone health and immune function crucial for runners
High-quality complete protein supports muscle repair and growth
May improve blood flow and oxygen delivery during exercise
foods.notes: Wild-caught contains more omega-3s than farmed. Aim for 2-3 servings per week. Sockeye has highest omega-3 content.

foods.name: Chicken Breast
benefits: Highest protein-to-calorie ratio among common proteins
B vitamins support energy metabolism during training
Lean protein supports muscle synthesis without excess fat
Selenium supports thyroid function and antioxidant defense
foods.notes: Versatile and quick to prepare. Pair with vegetables and whole grains for balanced recovery meals.

foods.name: Eggs (Whole)
benefits: Complete protein with highest bioavailability of any food
Choline supports brain function and muscle control
Leucine content optimizes muscle protein synthesis
Versatile and quick for busy training schedules
foods.notes: Eat the whole egg - yolk contains most nutrients. Pasture-raised have higher omega-3s. Great post-run breakfast.

foods.name: Greek Yogurt (Plain, 2%)
benefits: Probiotics support gut health crucial for nutrient absorption
High calcium supports bone density for high-impact running
Casein protein provides slow-release amino acids for recovery
Perfect post-run snack with fruit and granola
foods.notes: Choose plain and add your own fruit to control sugar. Excellent base for overnight oats and smoothies.

foods.name: Firm Tofu
benefits: Complete plant protein with all essential amino acids
Calcium-set tofu excellent for bone health in female athletes
Isoflavones may support bone density and hormonal balance
Versatile for any cuisine and quick to prepare
foods.notes: Press before cooking to improve texture. Choose calcium-set varieties for highest calcium content.

foods.name: Tempeh
benefits: Fermented soy is more digestible with enhanced nutrients
Probiotics from fermentation support gut health
Higher protein than tofu with more fiber
Complete protein ideal for plant-based athletes
foods.notes: Steam or simmer before cooking to reduce bitterness. Excellent grilled or crumbled into dishes.

foods.name: Sardines (Canned in Olive Oil)
benefits: Exceptional omega-3 content for anti-inflammatory benefits
Bones provide significant calcium for bone health
Sustainable, low-mercury fish safe for regular consumption
Convenient protein source requiring no cooking
foods.notes: Eat the bones for calcium. Choose wild-caught in olive oil. Excellent on whole grain crackers or salads.

foods.name: Turkey Breast
benefits: Highest protein with lowest fat among poultry options
Tryptophan supports quality sleep for recovery
Selenium supports immune function during heavy training
Lean protein ideal for weight-conscious athletes
foods.notes: Fresh turkey breast preferred over processed deli meat. Great for meal prep with vegetables.

foods.name: Cottage Cheese (2%)
benefits: Casein protein provides slow-release amino acids overnight
Ideal before bed for overnight muscle recovery
High protein with moderate calories for lean body composition
Pairs well with fruit for satisfying recovery snack
foods.notes: Perfect nighttime protein for overnight recovery. Choose lower sodium versions when available.

foods.name: Shrimp
benefits: Astaxanthin is powerful antioxidant for recovery
Exceptionally lean with high protein density
Iodine supports thyroid function and metabolism
Quick to cook - ready in minutes for fast meals
foods.notes: Choose wild-caught when possible. Astaxanthin gives shrimp their pink color and provides antioxidant benefits.

categories.name: Treats
categories.description: Healthy indulgences that provide pleasure while offering nutritional benefits for athletes

foods.name: Dark Chocolate (70-85%)
benefits: Flavanols improve blood flow and may enhance exercise performance
Epicatechin may improve muscle efficiency and mitochondrial function
Magnesium supports muscle function and prevents cramps
Mood-boosting compounds support mental wellbeing during hard training
foods.notes: Choose 70%+ cacao for maximum flavanol content. 1-2 oz daily is the sweet spot for benefits.

foods.name: Raw Honey
benefits: Quick energy source with natural sugars for endurance
Antimicrobial properties may support immune health
Can soothe throat irritation from cold-weather running
Natural alternative to processed sugars in energy foods
foods.notes: Use as natural energy gel during long runs. Mix with water for homemade sports drink. Raw honey retains beneficial enzymes.

foods.name: Pure Maple Syrup
benefits: Contains 54 unique polyphenol compounds with antioxidant activity
Lower glycemic index than refined sugar for steadier energy
Quebecol compound unique to maple has anti-inflammatory properties
Natural source of quick energy for training
foods.notes: Grade B (now called Grade A Dark) has more minerals and antioxidants. Use in oatmeal or homemade energy bars.

foods.name: Coconut Butter
benefits: MCTs provide quick energy without carbohydrate dependence
Lauric acid supports immune function
Satisfying fat content helps with satiety
Fiber from coconut meat supports gut health
foods.notes: Different from coconut oil - includes the coconut meat. Excellent in smoothies or spread on toast.

foods.name: Cacao Nibs
benefits: Pure form of chocolate with maximum flavanol content
No added sugars - bitter chocolate flavor
Theobromine provides mild energy boost without jitters
Exceptional magnesium for muscle function
foods.notes: Add to trail mix, smoothies, or yogurt. Bitter flavor - pairs well with fruit for balance.

foods.name: Dried Mango (Unsweetened)
benefits: Natural quick energy for long runs and training
Beta-carotene supports immune function and recovery
Portable and doesn't require refrigeration
Satisfies sweet cravings with real fruit nutrition
foods.notes: Choose unsweetened/unsulfured varieties. Great alternative to commercial energy chews during runs.

foods.name: Frozen Banana Ice Cream
benefits: Blended frozen banana creates creamy ice cream texture
No added sugars - just naturally sweet fruit
Potassium helps prevent muscle cramps
Cooling treat perfect for hot summer training
foods.notes: Freeze ripe bananas and blend until creamy. Add cacao powder or nut butter for variations. Guilt-free dessert.

foods.name: Date-Nut Energy Balls
benefits: Perfect grab-and-go energy for training
Dates provide natural quick energy like commercial gels
Nuts add protein and healthy fats for sustained energy
Customizable with various nuts, seeds, and add-ins
foods.notes: Blend dates, nuts, and oats in food processor. Add cacao, coconut, or nut butter for variety. Keep refrigerated.

foods.name: Almond Butter (Natural)
benefits: Vitamin E protects muscles from exercise-induced oxidative damage
Magnesium prevents cramping during long runs
Healthy fats provide sustained energy
Perfect paired with banana or apple for pre-run fuel
foods.notes: Choose natural with no added oils or sugar. Stir well before use. Excellent on toast, in smoothies, or with fruit.

foods.name: Coconut Water
benefits: Natural electrolyte replacement without artificial ingredients
Exceptional potassium content prevents muscle cramps
More hydrating than water due to electrolyte content
Lower sugar than most commercial sports drinks
foods.notes: Natural sports drink alternative. Choose 100% coconut water with no added sugars. Great post-run hydration.
